label: AB2C_oP96_19_6a_12a_6a-002
title: Anhydrous $\beta$-D-Glucose (C$_{6}$H$_{12}$O$_{6}$) Structure
comments:
Anhydrous glucose can be found in nature in two forms: \begin{itemize} \item \href{current_web_home_dir/AB2C_oP96_19_6a_12a_6a-001}{$\alpha$-D-glucose} and \item \href{current_web_home_dir/AB2C_oP96_19_6a_12a_6a-001}{$\beta$-D-glucose} (this structure), and \item \href{current_web_home_dir/A6B14C7_mP54_4_6a_14a_7a-001}{$\alpha$-D-glucose monohydrate}. \end{itemize} ~ \vspace{-.25in} 
 This is a \href{../Tutorials/ChiralSpaceGroups}{chiral compound}. 
 The ``D'' indicates that a solution of this form of glucose will rotate polarized light to the right, while the ``L'' type rotates light to the left. 
 Only D-glucose is found in nature, but the L-type can be synthesized. 
 As $\beta$-L-glucose is the enantiomer of $\beta$-D-glucose its structure should be a mirror image of this one, but we have not been able to find a report of its structure. 
 $\alpha$- and $\beta$-D-glucose have the same AFLOW prototype label, AB2C\_oP96\_19\_6a\_12a\_6a. They are generated by the same symmetry operations with different sets of parameters ({\tt --params}) specified in their corresponding CIF files. 
 The hydrogen positions were approximated assuming an O-H bond length of 1{\AA} and knowledge of hydrogen bonding.
